ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to do orthographic, axonometric, and perspectival drawings. I also learned how to draft and use architectural tools.

I learned so much not only about different types of drawing, but also about my own art style and how I can push the boundaries of my artistic comfort zone.  Helped me improve a lot in terms of measurement, proportions, and angles as well
How to draw technical drawings, and learned to see the world with enhanced perception.

I learned a lot about how architects represent the world on paper through a variety of drawing techniques and projections  orthographic, perspective, axonometric drawing types, etc. My observational sketching drastically improved taking the course, and I learned how to draw using drafting tools (t-squre and triangles).
I learned how to represent structures in architecture through different styles of drawing: orthographic, isometric, perspectival, axonometric
I developed my ability to draw what I see, and learned more about drawing techniques that enable a more realistic drawing.
A greater appreciation and skillset for drawing architecture, things, and people.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: The syllabus was well-crafted, with the course gaining more complexity as the semester went on. I think concepts were clearly explained in lectures, and the professor and TF were always understanding and available. Weaknesses: I really wish there were examples included with the homework prompts; since almost all of us were drawing certain things in certain ways for the first time, that would've really helped. There was also so much work, I don't think it was intended to be a lot of work but it was.

Strength: The TA was great. 
Weakness: This course is supposed to be for people with no experience in architecture but the content actually assumed a lot of background knowledge that wasnt clearly instructed.

I think this course suffers a lot from being virtual this semester getting to be in person and watching the professor and TA actually draw in person would have been hugely helpful. One of the assignments in the course was a 'daily themes' assignment, where we were instructed to do a 15-minute drawing every day for the duration of the course. While I love the spirit of the assignment, I wish that we checked in and talked about these drawings during the class because I ended up falling pretty behind a couple of times.

The drawing assignment were very fun! They did take a lot of time and the daily drawings were really difficult to keep up with, especially with the amount of time and effort needed for the large weekly assignments.

Strengths: extremely fun, very open, great material and professor

Weaknesses: nothing comes to mind other than the work being time consuming, wouldnt say this is a weakness but rather an attribute to drawing

I appreciated the range of assignments and flexibility of being able to draw a variety of subjects. Could be improved by having better process for showing more of the instructor's work and other creative inspiration. The expectation for the quality of work expected of students was also fuzzy, so establishing these expectations in the beginning would have been helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everyone really tried their best to make this course work online, I don't think anything better could've been done.
The presentation of art suffered from the online format, but the professor and TA did an amazing job of making the virtual element work to the very best it could.

The in person drawing sessions were great! It was really difficult to focus during the Friday sections as they lasted longer than the seminar itself. I did really enjoy the online critique format, though!
The way lectures and activities were run, as well as individual section, felt very similar to real life and was well run
I wish we had been able to meet more often outside for section. Two hour Zoom sections were brutal, though the breaks did help.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course would've been a lot better in a non-covid year, so take this with a grain of salt. I would recommend this course to another student if they want to be an architect, I think they would gain useful skills. I would probably not recommend this course to someone who simply likes drawing; it's so much work, and you need proper motivation to do 20+ hour drawings of stairs. I would also only recommend taking this course in a semester with a light course-load, I only took 4 course credits this semester and it felt like too much work.
Yes.  I would recommend this course to students who wish to learn more about art and be pushed to experiment with different mediums and new perspectives on drawing.
It is required for Architecture majors. I would recommend taking after you familiarize yourself with architecture concepts in other classes.

Not unless you are an architecture major. I am not just took this for fun, which was a mistake. A number of students dropped the class midway through the semester because the workload was too great. I want to note that even if you find drawing fun, drawing with drafting tools (which comprise about half the assignments of the semester) is not especially fun and very work-intensive. This is really a formidable class, so if you aren't really interested in going into architecture, this probably isn't for you. 

(Additionally, the materials cost a lot of money...)

I would if you are an architecture major or interested in learned how to represent space and structures through in person drawings. This course feels essential for those interested in the subject as it has taught me a lot about the ways architects draw, as well as proper techniques and practices universal to the field.
Yes, whether you like architecture or not this is a fun class, but they should be ready to draw a LOT
For anyone interested in architecture and who likes drawing--absolutely!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were live virtual lectures, live virtual discussion sections, and occasional in-person drawing sessions.
In person drawing outings
Mostly virtual lectures and virtual crits, occasionally some sections where we would meet outside and draw in person
Some in person drawing sessions
In person lecture and activities
Met in person socially distanced a few times on site.
